Master Jing says:
The first chapter is called the introduction, the next nineteen chapters are the main teaching, and the eight chapters below the chapter on spiritual powers are the dissemination.
Although there is this division, it does not explain the reasons.
Now there are two explanations:

The first chapter is called the introduction, the next eight chapters are the main teaching. The main teaching of the One Vehicle bestows predictions to the three capacities. The fundamental purpose has already brought benefits, transforming those of the two vehicles out of the turbid waters.
The sutra below says:

In this sutra, only the One Vehicle is taught. Although in the past it disparaged the Å›rÄvakas who delight in the lesser teachings in front of the bodhisattvas, the Buddha truly teaches and transforms with the Great Vehicle.

Also, in the chapter on Devadatta, Bodhisattva Zhiji says to the Buddha of Abundant Treasures that he may return to his original land. Therefore, it is known that after the matter is finished, he then requests the return. It is clear that the place where the One Vehicle is taught is precisely the main point of the sutra.

If it is said that only the section where benefits are obtained is the main part without speaking of the One Vehicle, then in the chapter on Samantabhadra, countless bodhisattvas attained dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, and bodhisattvas as numerous as the dust particles in the trichiliocosm practiced the path of Samantabhadra. Or, taking half of the chapter on Dharma teachers and half of the eight chapters as the main part, because at the beginning of the chapter on Dharma teachers, the Buddha bestowed the prediction of bodhi to those ordinary beings and sages who were present and rejoiced in seeing and hearing it.

Or, the initial preface is the same as before, from the chapter on skillful means to the chapter on upholding, a total of twelve chapters, clarifying the realm of the One Vehicle. The chapter on the practice of peace and bliss and the chapter on the emergence from the earth, these two chapters, clarify the practice of the One Vehicle. From the chapter on the lifespan of the TathÄgata to the chapter on the always-disparaged, a total of five chapters, explain the fruition of the One Vehicle.

Explaining the realm causes one to know the provisional and real of the vehicle. It is advised to abandon the provisional and take up the real. The Å›rÄvakas, upon realizing this, finally receive the prediction.

Gradually attaining the superior virtues of the two states of causes and fruition. The bodhisattvas, upon knowing this, finally realize the path. Fully revealing the superior virtues accomplished by the fruition and causes.

Below the Chapter on Spiritual Powers is all called the distribution of the teaching, showing the entrustment, and receiving the order to carry it out. The reasons for these will all be explained below.

The treatise explains that the Chapter on the Introduction has seven kinds of accomplishments. Accomplishment means the meaning of being complete and perfect. It wants to clarify that the introduction is complete with seven meanings, and the seven meanings are perfect, which is not found in other sÅ«tras.

First, the accomplishment of the introductory section. Beginning with the general cause, it is complete and perfect. The mountain city is perfect, representing superiority over others, thus it alone gets the name of introduction, but in reality, all seven are introductions.

Second, the accomplishment of the assembly, which is below together with a great bhiká¹£u assembly. It is the perfection of number, practice, gathering merit, and dignified deportment. It is superior to other sÅ«tras.

Sixth is the accomplishment of the great assembly's present desire to hear the Dharma, which is shown by the passage at that time Maitreya Bodhisattva had this thought. Seventh is the accomplishment of Manjushri's answer, which is because he uses the knowledge of past lives to directly see the characteristics of past causes and effects, accomplishing ten kinds of things as if they were present, and therefore is able to answer, which is not found in other sutras.
Among the seven, it is divided into two: the first two are the general introduction, and the latter five are the specific introduction.
The general introduction has five parts:

First, generally showing what has been heard, second, the time of teaching, third, the teacher of the teaching, fourth, the place where the teaching was given, fifth, the audience to be reached. This completes the assembly, and the preface is only four. Thus have I heard is the first, in order to make people give rise to faith and show what has been heard.
The treatise only speaks of two accomplishments in the preface:
First, the city, second, the mountain.
These two places are superior and different from other sÅ«tras, so they are specifically mentioned;
The time of hearing and the Buddha are no different from other sÅ«tras. Although the sÅ«tra has all of this, it does not specifically mark the superiority.
Thus have I heard and so forth are analyzed in three aspects:
First, the reason for speaking, second, the rationale for establishing it, third, directly explaining the text.

As for the reason for speaking, it is like the MahÄvastu and other sÅ«tras speaking of its origin. When the Buddha was about to enter nirvÄá¹‡a, the Buddha ordered that if there were doubts, they should be asked. At that time, UpÄli and Ä€nanda taught Ä€nanda to ask about four matters:

First, after the Buddha's nirvana, which one should the bhiká¹£us take as their teacher? Second, on what should they rely to abide? Third, how should they punish evil-natured bhiká¹£us? Fourth, what words should be placed at the beginning of all sÅ«tras?
The Buddha taught:

Later, when Ä€nanda compiled the canon, he still relied on the Buddha's teachings. The detailed reasons are all as explained in the sÅ«tras.
The reason for establishing this is to enable sentient beings to give rise to faith and obedience.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says:
Thus have I heard gives rise to faith.
Believe, receive, and practice gives rise to wisdom.

Faith is the ability to enter, wisdom is the ability to cross over. Faith is the initial foundation for entering the Dharma, wisdom is the profound method for ultimate realization. If one has faith, then the principles spoken of will be in accord. If there is accord, then the way of teacher and disciple will be established. Because of faith, all the teachings spoken of can be in accord with. Because of accord, the two groups of speaker and listener establish the relationship of teacher and disciple.
Herein, faith is briefly explained in ten ways:

First, the initial cause for progressing to the ultimate fruit. According to the Benevolent Kings and other sutras, it is the initial cause for progressing to the holy stages. Therefore, the forty minds take faith as the foremost.

At the very beginning, one must possess ten virtues and arouse three wondrous contemplations in order to give rise to the mind of great enlightenment. The mind of great enlightenment takes wholesome roots as its essence, takes good friends as its conditions, and takes non-retrogression as its impetus.
Wholesome roots are faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.
Therefore, the Compendium of the Great Vehicle says:
The power of pure supremacy, the mind of solidity and advancement, is called the initial cultivation of bodhisattvas, for innumerable great eons.
Second, the gradual basis for entering into the principle of truth. All treatises say that before entering the holy position, there is the faculty of faith and the power of faith.
Because there is the faculty of faith, myriad wholesome practices arise from it;
Because there is the power of faith, the four demons cannot subdue it. Therefore, at the beginning of this sutra, it first causes faith to arise.

Third, the pure evidence of penetrating the wondrous truth. It can transcend evil destinies and leave the causes of lowly poverty, therefore, after entering the holy, one realizes the four indestructible faiths. Because of faith in the Three Jewels, one can transcend evil destinies. Because of faith in precepts, one leaves the causes of lowly poverty. Therefore, the treatises also say there is the realization of faith.

Fourth, it is the basis for the joy of bearing supreme virtue. The VibhÄá¹£Ä says that for those who have faith, it is like a fine hand that tastes the flavor of the Dharma. Those who study the Buddha's teachings are like great dragons and elephants. Faith is their hand, renunciation is their tusk, mindfulness is their neck, and wisdom is their head. On their two shoulders they carry the accumulated good dharmas.
Because elephants use their trunk as a hand to drink and eat, those who study the Buddha's teachings first give rise to faith.

Fifth, it is the primordial womb of the seven treasures of the sages. Because faith is the first of the Dharma treasures, learners are great merchants, and the fundamental plan is to obtain the Dharma treasures and the treasures of the sages, so they first give rise to faith.

The seven treasures of the sages are faith, precepts, learning, renunciation, wisdom, conscience, and shame. Faith is one of them.

As for desire being the basis, it is because it gives rise to hope. As for intention giving rise to it, it is because it repeatedly arouses it. The ten sincere and excellent requests, the Spring and Autumn Annals say:

If there is clear faith, even the fur of a marsh and pond, and the vegetables of pondweed and duckweed, can be offered to ghosts and spirits, and can be served to the public and the king, how much more so for a gentleman to establish the faith of the two countries.

Among these ten meanings, the first eight rely on the truth, and the last two rely on convention. Therefore, the sutra begins with thus. The meaning of the sutra is personally heard from the Buddha, free from the errors of addition and subtraction, in order to cause sentient beings to give rise to faith, joy, and practice in accordance with the teachings.
As for the correct explanation of the text, the Buddha Land Treatise says:
The words 'thus' turn based on four meanings.

First, from the perspective of the Buddha, the teachings of the buddhas of the three times are the same and not different, so it is called thus; because they teach the same, it is called is.

As for I have heard, the bodhisattva who transmits the Dharma points to himself and says that such Dharma was personally heard from the Buddha, and is therefore called I have heard, it is not that the I definitely belongs to one person.
I refers to the conventional designation of the aggregates. However, there are three kinds of I:
First, the falsely grasped I, which refers to the I that non-Buddhists arbitrarily conceive.
Second, the I that is provisionally established, which refers to the bliss, purity, permanence, and I of great nirvÄá¹‡a, because the two vehicles' inversions are strongly refuted and established.
Third, the I that is widely known in the world, which refers to what is commonly transmitted in the world, such as Devadatta and Vá¹›ddhi.
Now, the one who transmits the Dharma follows the world and points to himself as I, which is different from the first two. It is the great I that is without self.
Question:
The Buddha's teachings are originally to eliminate the grasping of self. Why not say no self but say I have heard?
Answer:
There are four meanings:
First, it is easy to speak. If one speaks of no self, it applies to the aggregates, sense bases, and elements. Who is this referring to?
Second, it accords with the world.
Third, it eliminates fear of no self. If one says there is no self, for whom should one cultivate and study?
Fourth, there is self and other, defilement and purity, cause and effect, activities, etc., so it is called self.
Question:
If so, why not use one's name but only call oneself I?
Answer:
There are three meanings:

First, it shows not contradicting worldly conventions. Although the teaching reveals the truth, the words do not contradict worldly conventions. Although the principle reveals the wondrous, the words do not contradict the coarse. It wants to show that the truth of ultimate reality is not apart from worldly conventions.
Second, self means the meaning of being the master, controller, and sovereign.
The Collection of Dharma Transmission says:
There are three Ä€nandas:
The first Ananda means joy, and he held the Sravaka canon.
The second Ananda means joyful virtue, and he held the Pratyekabuddha canon.
The third Ananda means joyful ocean, and he held the Bodhisattva canon.
This is just one person, whose name is distinguished according to his virtues.

Therefore, Ananda is very learned, remembers what he hears, and accumulates what he hears. He is fully equipped with the three kinds of wisdom and holds both the text and meaning. He has mastery over the three baskets of teachings. If his name is called, although it accords with the correct principle, it does not have the meaning of mastery over all dharmas.
Therefore, he is called 'I' and not Ananda.
The third I means intimacy. The world commonly says I see, I hear. This is considered to be intimate evidence.

If it is said Ananda heard, it may not be intimate hearing but transmitted by others. Now, it is shown that he personally heard what the World-Honored One said, not what he heard from others. In order to break others' webs of doubt, he does not call his name but only says I heard.
Heard means the ear faculty producing consciousness to listen and accept what is spoken.
Now, abandoning the ear and taking the self as the general term, it is said I heard.

Although in the Mahayana, the faculties, consciousnesses, and mental factors are combined to be called hearing, the faculties are superior to consciousnesses, etc. in five ways, so the faculties are called hearing.
The five meanings of the faculties are: relying, producing, belonging, assisting, and being like the faculties.

Being like the faculties means that when the faculties are clear or obscure, the consciousnesses are also clear or obscure. If one only hears sounds, it can be said to be in the ears, but since it takes names and meanings as objects, it is in the mind.
Therefore, the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says:

Hearing means inference. The ear faculty is called hearing because it directly hears sounds and serves as a door for the mind, since the mind only hears through it. Taking the two as doors, perfuming occurs in the general [consciousness], and what is accomplished through hearing is generally called hearing. Abandoning the specific ear and mind, it is generally called I heard.
Question:
At that time, SubhÅ«ti personally saw, realized, and knew what the Buddha said. Why did he only say I heard and not I saw and so forth?
Answer:
There are three meanings:
First, to realize the profound truth, one must first hear the Dharma. Names and phrases express meanings, not forms and so forth.
Second, in this realm, sound is the Buddha's work. Sound is the basis for names and phrases.
Third, to attain enlightenment, one must be perfumed by hearing. Because the perfuming of hearing results in transcendence.
Therefore, at the beginning of the sÅ«tra, it does not say seeing, realizing, knowing, but only I heard.

In reality, at that time, one also sees the Buddha speaking. In other buddha-lands, light and so forth are the Buddha's work. One can say seeing and so forth. One should discriminate within this meaning.
Question:
Does the Buddha speak the Dharma and say I can hear, or does the Buddha not speak and say I hear?
Answer:
There are two interpretations.
First, the Dragon Army and others say:
The Buddha has only three dharmas, namely great concentration, wisdom, and compassion.

Having long been free from conceptual proliferation, he never spoke the Dharma. Due to the power of the Buddha's compassionate original vows, the forms and meanings of the texts arise in the consciousness of sentient beings. Although these forms and meanings arise directly based on the power of their own wholesome roots, they are called the Buddha's teachings based on the powerful conditions. They are called what I have heard due to the power of the ear faculty and one's own mental transformation, and this is their essential nature.
Therefore, AsvabhÄva says:
According to the eight periods of time, the forms and meanings that appear directly or indirectly in the consciousness of the hearer are taken as their essential nature.
He himself raises a question:
If that is so, how can the bodhisattvas speak?
The treatise says at the beginning:

The bodhisattvas who have already well entered the MahÄyÄna in front of the BhagavÄn, in order to reveal the vast essence of the MahÄyÄna, expound the chapter on the compendium of the MahÄyÄna, and therefore raise this question.
The treatise further answers by itself:
This is said because it is their dominant influence. For example, due to the dominant power of the gods, etc., one can obtain spells, etc. in dreams. Therefore, the sutra also says:
From the beginning of attaining enlightenment to the end of nirvana, in between he did not speak a single word.
Like a mother's teeth pointing, the child understands when born.
Second, it is said by Bandhuprabha and others:

The Buddha's body is endowed with aggregates, sense bases, elements, etc., and is called free from conceptual proliferation due to being free from discrimination. How can it be said to be free from conceptual proliferation if it preaches the Dharma?

It means that by the power of the conditions of the fundamental wholesome roots and vows of those who are to hear it, the characteristics of the text and meaning arise in the consciousness of the TathÄgata. These characteristics of the text and meaning arise from the wholesome roots of the Buddha's benefiting others and are called the Buddha's teaching. Although those who hear it do not directly obtain them in their own consciousnesses, they clearly appear as if they were those characteristics, and therefore it is called 'I have heard.'
Vasubandhu says:
It is said that because the differences in consciousness of other continua cause the arising of differences in consciousness in other continua, they are each other's dominant conditions.
For this reason, the sutra says:
The Dharma I have taught is like the leaves in my hand, the Dharma I have not taught is like the leaves in the forest. It is like a jewel or a heavenly drum, which function without thought.
Here, the two explanations follow those two texts, explaining them in an alternating manner.

It should be known that the statement Thus have I heard is intended to avoid the faults of addition, subtraction, and error. It means that this Dharma was heard by me from the Buddha, not from others. It shows that

the hearer has the ability to bear [the Dharma], and that everything he has heard is free from the faults of addition, subtraction, and error, unlike foolish people who are unable to bear [the Dharma].

Whatever is heard, if one is unable to avoid increase, decrease, or division, when compiling the Dharma, those who transmit the Buddha's teachings rely on the TathÄgata's teachings and first say these words, in order to cause sentient beings to respectfully believe and accept, saying, Such and such Dharma I have heard from the Buddha, the text and meaning are definite, without any increase or decrease. Therefore, those who hear should first listen correctly, contemplate in accordance with principle, and diligently cultivate and study.
The sÅ«tra says: At one time.
The commentary says:
The second is the time when the teaching was spoken.
This has two meanings:
First, when the Dharma King initiates teaching, all the receptive capacities gather, and the speaking and listening are completed, collectively called at one time.
Second, the speaker and listener meet together, and the time is no different, therefore it is said at one time. The receptive capacities and the responding transformation have no separate time.
First, based on the uninterrupted continuity of moments of speaking and listening, it is provisionally called at one time.
This has two explanations:

First, the time of reality: although the two groups of expounders and listeners are only in the present, the five aggregates and all conditioned factors are born and perish in a moment. In this present dharma, there is the meaning of repaying the past and attracting the future. The past that is repaid is provisionally called the past, and the future that is attracted is provisionally called the future. The present is spoken of in relation to these two. These past and future worlds are both provisionally established on the present dharma. The five aggregates and all conditioned factors of the expounders and listeners are born and perish in a moment, continuing before and after. The completion of the matter is provisionally established as the three times, and is generally called at one time. It is not the one time of a single birth and cessation.

Second, the time of consciousness only: the two groups of expounders and listeners transform the three time appearances on the conscious mind and give rise to them. They are actually in the present, but according to the limited duration of the mind, they transform into short or long. The completion of the matter is generally called at one time.
It is like what is seen in a dream, which is said to have many lifetimes. In the awakened state, it is only the mind, and there are no real objects at all;

The minds of the listeners change in the three times in the same way. This is only the object of the mental consciousness, an unconditioned dharma included in the aggregate of formations, the element of mental objects, and the sense sphere of mental objects.

As for the expression at one time, one, it is not definite in terms of a moment; two, it is not definite in terms of a continuum; three, it is not definite in terms of the four periods, the six periods, the eight periods, the twelve periods, etc.; four, it is not definite in terms of the number of years and seasons after the attainment of enlightenment being called at one time. It is simply that when the faculties of the listeners are ripe and they feel the Buddha's teaching, and when the teacher, out of compassion, speaks in response to the capacities, and when the teaching and listening are completed, it is collectively called at one time.

As for not being definite in terms of a moment, etc., the faculties of the assembly listening to the Dharma may be dull, and although the teaching may be short, it takes a long time for them to understand.
